Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: They guide a patient on proper usage and potential side effects of a new prescription medication.
Story: It’s Saturday afternoon, and I’m behind the pharmacy counter, explaining to Mrs. Lee how to take her new blood pressure medication. She looks anxious, so I slow down, making sure she understands the side effects and what to do if she feels dizzy. My phone vibrates in my pocket—probably my stepdad. He’s been texting more lately, ever since Mom’s surgery. I promised I’d check in with them every weekend, but I haven’t replied since last Sunday. Guilt gnaws at me. I know they expect me to be present, to show I care, especially now. But Mrs. Lee’s eyes are fixed on me, waiting for reassurance. I can’t rush this; my patients rely on me to be thorough and attentive. My phone buzzes again. I feel torn, the weight of both roles pressing on me. I want to be a good step-child, to show my parents they matter, but right now, I’m the only pharmacist on duty. My heart pounds as I finish counseling Mrs. Lee, my mind already racing with what I should do next.
